titleStmt.title: Black Waves: Vaziri (2023) Traces African Enslavement in the Persian Gulf through Film

dhq:bio.p: Zeinab is a Ph.D. student and Graduate Research Assistant at the School of Information Science & Learning Technologies (SISLT) iSchool at the University of Missouri. She is studying the use of innovative technologies such as virtual reality and video games, and she is interested in digital, media, and archival studies and human-computer interaction.

dhq:abstract.p: Parisa Vaziri's Racial Blackness and Indian Ocean Slavery: Iran's Cinematic Archive offers a profound examination of Blackness and slavery in Iranian cinema, delving into historical representations through fīlmfārsī and Indigenous theatrical traditions. Vaziri's critique highlights the historiographical neglect of Indian Ocean slavery, emphasizing the marginalized narratives of the enslaved and presenting maps to illustrate African migrations and slave trade routes, enriching our understanding of global history.

dhq:teaser.p: Dive into our review of Parisa Vaziri's Racial Blackness and Indian Ocean Slavery: Iran's Cinematic Archive to uncover the overlooked narratives of enslaved African people in Iranian cinema, a rich tapestry of history and film that challenges established truths.

div.p: Parisa Vaziri's Racial Blackness and Indian Ocean Slavery: Iran's Cinematic Archive (2023) begins with a sentence from one of Marc Nichanian's books, The Historiographic Perversion (2009).Marc Nichanian was a Professor of Armenian Studies at Columbia University from 1996 to 2007. He is currently a Visiting Professor at Sabanci University, Instanbul, in the Department of Cultural Studies. It reads: Historical objectivity regarding facts, the quiet assurance of established history, is no more than a luxury of those who can enjoy truth without conflict . Nichanian's concept of historiographic perversion foreshadows a book deeply entrenched in the critical examination of historical objectivity. By opening her book with this sentence, Vaziri shows readers that her work will scrutinize the very foundation of what is commonly accepted as historical truth, questioning the neutrality and assurance of established history. Readers can expect Vaziri's book to offer a profound inquiry into the writing of history, exploring the influence of power, ideology, and conflict on the construction of historical narratives.

Racial Blackness and Indian Ocean Slavery: Iran's Cinematic Archive (2023) is indeed a profound exploration of representations of Blackness and historical undercurrents of slavery within Iranian cinema. Vaziri, a scholar of comparative literature, delves into the complex layers of Fīlmfārsī from the 1950s and 1970sFīlmfārsī is a term used in pre-revolutionary Iranian cinema criticisim that was coined by Iranian film critic Hushang Kavusi. The term is used to describe what was perceived as low-quality films, mostly copied from Bollywood cinema, with poor plots and arranged with dance and singing., the Indigenous theatrical tradition of siyāh bāzī, or the Persian Black play, and the portrayal of the zār ritual, offering a nuanced reading of how those films reflect and obscure the ties to African enslavement.

The origins of this book can be traced back to Vaziri's PhD dissertation, which was written during a time of social upheaval in Iran. The 2022 protests over Mahsa Amini's tragic death provided a poignant backdrop, influencing Vaziri's approach to gender representation in Iranian cinema. That personal connection adds a layer of urgency and authenticity to her work. Furthermore, while it is very tricky to translate words specific to Iranian culture into English, Vaziri manages it well, particularly with words like ungendered Blackness and eunuchism. Her translation of Persian words such as naqqali and pardahdari (literally, screen holding) into English is more than a linguistic exercise; it is a cultural bridge that enriches the reader's understanding of Iranian cinematic and social fabric. Persian terms, theoretical concepts, and ideas are indicated with italics in this book.

div.head: Why Cinema?
div.p: Vaziri presents a compelling argument against the contemporary extractive nature of content production. She posits cinema not merely as a form of entertainment but as a powerful medium for reflection and intellectual engagement. Her perspective resonates with the thoughts of philosopher Bernard Stiegler, who eloquently remarked that a process of global unification has taken place through cinema . Vaziri's book underscores the unifying power of film to transcend cultural and temporal boundaries, offering a shared space for global narratives and dialogues.

div.head: Indian Ocean Slavery and the Lack of Archival Resources
div.p: Vaziri's examination is particularly striking in its critique of the historiographical neglect of Indian Ocean slavery, which starkly contrasts with the attention given to Atlantic and trans-Saharan slavery. That lacuna in historical discourse, compounded by the scarcity of archival sources, is a silent testimony to the marginalized narratives of the enslaved. Related scholarship shows both African migrations across the Indian Ocean, and the differences between three slave trade routes: trans-Saharan, Atlantic Ocean, and Indian Ocean.

In her exemplary work, the author articulates a significant challenge in the study of slavery: the scarcity of archival materials. She notes that the narrative of Indian Ocean slavery, as in other regions, is often pieced together from material evidence that was not created by the enslaved themselves, but rather from records shaped by bureaucratic narratives or formalized correspondence. Such indirect documentation creates a barrier to fully understanding the enslaved perspective.

Further, the author highlights the critical role of digital media in preserving cinematic history. She reflects on how a multitude of films, pivotal to her research, would have been lost if not for the digital age. Those pre-revolutionary works, previously at the mercy of inadequate storage solutions, faced further jeopardy from the deliberate destruction during the 1979 Iranian Revolution, resulting in the demolition of a significant portion of Iran's cinematic infrastructure as well as the loss of countless historical film records. The transition to digital platforms has not only resurrected those films from potential obscurity but allowed for the conservation and continued examination of Iran's rich cinematic legacy.

div.head: Significance of Oil and Sugar Cane
div.p: Vaziri also delves deeply into the profound impact of oil on the socio-economic fabric of Iran, underscoring the role of oil since the early 20th century. As the nation's premier industry, oil reshaped Iran's economy as well as its cultural and social landscapes. The author explores how the legacy of the slave trade is intertwined with oil's narrative, noting that the descendants of enslaved Africans, often traded in Persian Gulf ports, still live predominantly along the coastal regions. In this way, the south of Iran becomes a dual symbol: a bastion of petroleum wealth and a silent witness to the legacy of slavery.

Vaziri goes beyond oil, illuminating how the region's history is rich with other forms of commerce such as date cultivation, pearling, and, notably, sugarcane farming in Khuzistan — historically known as the land of sugar. Those industries, sustained in part by slave labor, predate oil's dominance and hint at a broader spectrum of economic activities that have shaped Iran's history.

Moreover, the book suggests that oil and the slave labor that once bolstered the pearling industry form a subconscious thread in the tapestry of Iranian cinema. That underlying theme is presented as a metaphorical undercurrent that has, perhaps inadvertently, influenced the narratives and stories told through Iranian films. Vaziri's insightful analysis aims to bring to light these submerged connections, suggesting that the history of slavery and the development of the Iranian film industry are not just parallel stories but are profoundly connected. As Vaziri writes, Oil is the key element, the unconscious of the Iranian film industry. But it is also the case that pearling — and the slave labor that fueled it — is the unconscious of oil . She includes here a frame from the opening of Bahram Beyzai's Bashu, The Little Stranger (1989), which depicts the titular child peering through an abyss of sugar cane. The connection between slave labor and sugar cultivation dips into an undatable chasm that echoes through this scene in the ambiguity of stalk identification.

Racial Blackness and Indian Ocean Slavery: Iran's Cinematic Archive explores how the traditional Persian performance art of siyāh bāzī, or black play, which often involves a character in blackface, was woven into Iranian cinema before the revolution. The art form, which features a character known as the siyāh who often annoys or mocks authority figures, has not been thoroughly examined by film experts, especially regarding its transition to film and its historical links to actual slavery.

The author points out that when siyāh bāzī moved from the stage to the screen, the art form lost some of its original meaning due to the way that films were edited and the complex symbols used in them. While such films might remind us of Iran's past with African slavery, they often reduce the siyāh character to a simple stereotype, stripping away the historical context. Thus, there remains substantial debate about whether siyāh bāzī in films really represents the same thing as the racist practice of blackface, which is recognized globally.

In the first chapter, the author argues that the way siyāh bāzī is shown in films highlights the problems with how we think about this tradition. Films from before the Iranian revolution show the siyāh character as less complex and more disconnected from its roots in African slavery. This contrasts with the tendency today, both in academic and popular discussions, to try to ignore or deny the siyah's connections to slavery. However, Vaziri suggests that the reality of slavery disrupts these comfortable views, showing that the context through which we understand the siyāh character in films is not as solid or trustworthy as we might think.

In Farukh Ghafārī's classic black-and-white film, Shab-e Qoozi (Night of the Hunchback; 1964), there is a scene that encapsulates the complex layers of social commentary surrounding the siyāh bāzī that Vaziri examines. The scene features a white actor in blackface making an entrance, inquiring in broken Persian whether his master has enjoyed the music. As his indifferent master leisurely inhales from his hookah, the character calls out, With your permission, may this house-born slave [ghulām-i khānahzād] provide entertainment? Musicians, play! The character, referred to as a house-born slave, performs a subservient act, gracefully pouring liquid from a pitcher on a mantel into a diminutive cup before balancing it atop his head. He then commences to dance with a backward bend so low that the master can effortlessly take the cup .

The author dedicates Chapter 2 to the ritual of zār, which, in the context of Iranian modernity marked by the oil boom and the official end of slavery under Reza Shah in 1928Reza Shah Pahlavi (1878-1944) was an Iranian military officer and the founder of the Pahlavi dynasty, which was the last Iranian royal dynasty, ruling for almost 54 years between 1925 and 1979., represents a paradoxical call for the resurgence of the Black slave as a symbol of healing. This juxtaposition suggests that the legacy of slavery remains unresolved and continues to require healing, a theme that resonates in Iranian cinema of the 1960s, especially in narratives set in the south of Iran where Black characters often embody the role of healers.

Zār, as a practice, is prevalent across various regions, from Southwest Asia to the Persian Gulf and from North Africa to parts of South Asia and East Africa. It is characterized by cathartic processes involving movement, rhythm, and secrecy, leading to a loss of consciousness and serving as a form of communal therapy rather than a descent into despair. The author points out that zār operates on the principle of equality; despite its more frequent practice in impoverished Black communities, zār affects individuals universally. This egalitarian aspect of zār is also echoed in Ethiopian belief systems, where it is said that everyone possesses a zār.

From the film Bashu, the Little Stranger (1984), directed by Baharm Beyzai, Vaziri highlights a poignant moment where Na'i, the mother figure, is desperately seeking a cure for her son, Bashu. The local doctor's discriminatory assertion that his treatments are not meant for people of that color starkly contrasts with the ethos of zār, which does not discriminate. The incident is meticulously captured by Beyzai, underscoring zār as a force that sees no color, a stark reminder of the egalitarianism deeply rooted in this cultural practice. From zār, we glean the profound lesson of inherent equality among all people.

Chapter 4 provides a detailed analysis of the film Bashu, The Little Stranger (1984), directed by Baharm Beyzai alongside other famous Iranian films foregrounding phenotypically inflected racism. Vaziri's commentary on the representation of Blackness in the film Bashu, The Little Stranger is particularly revealing. She discusses the character's otherness and the societal reactions to his skin color, reflecting the broader societal issues regarding race and identity. In the film a boy from the south of Iran is lost after fleeing home for his life; his family has been killed during the Iran-Iraq war. He is saved and trained by a middle-aged woman (Na'i) in the north of Iran.

The film's dialog choices represent the mindsets of local people. At the start of the film, Bashu's mother finds him in the paddy field and expresses repulsion for Bashu's dark skin color, wondering aloud if he has escaped from a coal mine. Town dwellers find Bashu's Blackness a subject of derision and comedy. For example, the village shopkeeper insultingly Na'i an extra bar of soap as a means of insulting the Blackness of Bashu's skin. Throughout the film, across numerous scenes, a group of young boys encircles and bullies Bashu upon seeing him.

When Na'i's relatives come to visit her, non of them see Bashu as a child of Iran, a recognizable brother or son, and they can't resist remarking upon Bashu's charcoal color. They gather on a carpet, palaver, and pass around tea, reprimanding Na'i for her reckless decision to host the supposed foreigner, while various family members physically assess Bashu. An aunt gropes Bashu's head in search of lice; an uncle demands dental inspection. A small girl Bashu had earlier glimpsed from the window with intrigued curiosity crawls toward him on the carpet and swabs his face with her finger, which she examines, disappointed. Bashu lowers his head in shame. In another famous scene, Na'i bathes her own children in the river and then tricks Bashu into the water, furiously scrubbing away at his dark skin and nearly drowning him, hoping to remove his color as if removing a stain: Sefid nibeh ke nibeh (No, he won’t become white).

div.head: Renaming Slaves
div.p: The book then delves into the historical practice of renaming slaves, highlighting how such acts were used to strip individuals of their identity, a brutal facet of dehumanization. In Southwest Asia as elsewhere, renaming individuals with non-human names was one means by which slaveholders asserted control over the identities of the people they enslaved. In her insightful commentary on the character Bashu, Vaziri unpacks the lasting psychological effects of slavery. In the film's opening scene, for example, Na'i confronts Bashu, reducing him to a nameless, inferior status by denigrating his color and intelligence, thus negating his humanity: You are black, you are dumb, you have no name. Every human being has a name.

Vaziri further explores the paradox of Bashu's Blackness within the film, which is presented as neither Persian nor Arab, leaving him without a cultural anchor. The character's name, Bashu, is revealed by the director, Beyzai, to be a creative amalgamation derived from the Persian verbs to be [budan] and to reside [bashidan]. Thus, his name lends Bashu an existence and a place albeit through a constructed identity. This intricate detail underscores the complex layers of identity and belonging, particularly for those marked by the legacy of slavery.

In the second part of Chapter 4, Vaziri turns to another film, Amir Naderi's The Runner (1984), which is also about a young boy (Amiro) in the south of Iran. While Amiro is not marked as Black like Bashu is, his character mirrors societal attitudes towards race and humanity, suggesting a more innocent and unprejudiced perspective that could be the key to overcoming racial biases.

Vaziri discusses an important scene in this film in which physical power, like labor, is racialized through the juxtaposition of the white American and European foreigners who come to the port to get their shoes shined with the figure of Amiro bent at their feet, revealing his imprisonment within labor. As Vaziri writes, Amiro intermittently stares out into the ocean and fantasizes about being taken away by one of the large white ships: How white…how beautiful .

In another poignant sequence from The Runner, we witness young children valiantly attempting to scale rock mounds. The camera captures their endeavors from a high angle, tracking the children's ascent only to follow their subsequent and inevitable descent each time they falter. This visual narrative eloquently conveys the Sisyphean nature of Amiro's existence, underscoring the futility and servitude that mark his life's toil. The director employs this vantage point not merely as a cinematic technique but as a storytelling device, inviting viewers to empathize with Amiro's relentless yet unrewarding struggle.

Finally, Vaziri addresses the cultural and nationalistic forces that shape the discourse on race in Iran. She critiques the persistent mythologizing of Iran's Aryan past, which has influenced modern perceptions and discussions about race and identity.

Haji Firuz is a fictional character in Iranian folklore who appears in the streets by the beginning of Nowruz (Iranian New Year). His face is covered in soot and he is clad in bright red clothes and a felt hat. He dances through the streets while singing and playing the tambourine. Vaziri's examination of cultural figures like Haji Firuz and the influence of Aryanism provides a critical look at how nationalism and historical narratives have been constructed and the impact they have on contemporary society.In the traditional songs of Iran, Haji Firuz introduces himself as a sef trying to cheer people whom he refers to as his lords.

Haji Firuz symbolizes Iran's complex history with slavery as a figure whose performances evoke images of servitude. Contemporary Iranian culture often seeks to trace its roots to the pre-Islamic era and ZoroastrianismZoroastrianism, also known as Mazdayasna and Behdin, is an Iranian religion and one of the world's oldest organized faiths. It is based on the teachings of the Iranian-speaking prophet Zoroaster., driven by nationalist sentiments and a desire to validate cultural practices. This nationalistic drive stems from historical figures like Reza Shah, who promoted the idea of an Aryan Persian identity and the belief that the Persian king Cyrus the Great (590-529 BC) abolished slavery in Iran. Vaziri's work challenges such misconceptions by highlighting Iran's history of slavery, particularly in the context of films produced after 1953, which reflect the nationalistic ideologies of early 20th-century Iran. Aryanism, a significant nationalist ideology, continues to shape Iran's identity debates, influencing Iran's self-perception as white, racially distinct, and separate from its regional neighbors in the Middle East.

The concluding chapter brings us to the Collective for Black Iranians, a group that emerged in the wake of the Black Lives Matter movement, which serves as a contemporary challenge to traditional historiography. The collective's digital aesthetics and the narratives they spawn push back against the denial of racial legacies in the history of Indian Ocean slavery. The book posits that such digital communities are crafting counternarratives that protest the prevailing state of unacknowledged anti-Blackness in Southwest Asia and North Africa.

Vaziri's work is a crucial contribution to media studies, offering insightful critiques and celebrating cinema's potential to generate intellectual discussion. This book is highly recommended for those interested in the intersection of film, culture, and history, as well as anyone seeking to understand the profound ways in which our global stories are woven together in the frames of cinema.

div.head: Addendum
div.p: In delving into Parisa Vaziri's book, it is fascinating to note the resurgence of an old Iranian song in a modern Bollywood film, sparking renewed interest and appreciation. Jamal Jamaloo Kudu, a song that first resonated with audiences in the 1950s when performed by the Kharazmi Girls High School's Shirazi Choir, has found its way back into popular culture. The song, which has been a traditional favorite at weddings, was reimagined in Sandeep Reddy Vanga's film Animal, released on December 1, 2023, with Bobby Deol's character making a memorable entrance to its catchy tune.

This song, with roots tracing back to a poem by the esteemed Iranian poet Bijan Samandar, is a charming duet between a white Iranian woman and a Black man from southern Iran, whose ancestry is linked to Zanzibar. The lyrics convey a tender narrative where the woman expresses her deep affection, while the man responds with lighthearted invitations to dance, admiring her beauty in a playful exchange. The juxtaposition of their distinct heritages within the song's lyrics and the mutual admiration they express stands in poignant contrast to historical racial tensions.

The enduring popularity of Jamal Jamaloo Kudu serves as a cultural bridge, illustrating the seamless assimilation of African influences into Iranian culture. It defies the divisive views often associated with historical intercultural interactions, championing the idea of unity in diversity. This song remains a vibrant celebration of cultural harmony and a poignant reminder of the significance of inclusivity in our global society.
